content.description:
Pull some hard moves to the ledge. Stay on the left side of the arete for a few moves until you can swing back on to the arete on the right. Nice climbing, would be worthy of an extra star if it stayed off the ledge.

Fun route.
content.protection: Bolts
content.location: On a south facing wall 50ft right of Vertigo.

content.description: Hard moves of the ground leads to nice climbing.
content.protection: Bolts
content.location: Right of Mind the Gap

content.description: Scramble up the easy wide crack to the ledge. Up the crack (#3 & #2 Camalots) until you can move left and follow bolts up the face and arete to anchor. Superb moves on great rock.
content.protection: 1 each 3 & 2 Camalots. Bolts
content.location: On the south west face of TSA Tower. 20ft right of Turbulence Crack.

climbs.name: Under the Radar
climbs.fa: W. Brown, R. Suggett, D. Jones

content.description: This was a hard one to set.  Now that it is done, we think you will like it.  The rock was challenging for establishing bolts.  So the second bolt is a bit high.  This was the best placement, and stance, and crux.  Do not thrash here,  Back step and find the beta intensive easy clip.  But make the dam clip or deck.  If you do not see the easy stemming sequence, you could get some small cams in the corner to cover the move,  You would have to pull them after setting the draw. Next is a swing around the arete off a jug and into a right foot hole on the polished face. Otherwise, your movement is normal as you walk the ramp to the second crux just below the chains.  Great rock and face climbing here.  Fun steep moves.
content.protection: Seven QDs and three runners.  Clip the third and forth bolt long!
content.location: Turn north at the end of the trail  and edge to the down climb with a blue fixed line.  Follow cairns for just a few meters to the first climb you see.  This is an easy approach compared to the rest of the Air Strip.

content.description: Nice clean crack. Burly from the first to the second roof. Have a rest, then crank to the belay.
content.protection: Cams from .4 to 3 Camalot. Triple #1 and double #2
content.location: On the west face of TSA Tower.

content.description: Easy roof turning onto big edges outside the crack all the way up.  Takes gear well but the face edges are a bit crispy.  This took a bit of cleaning.  You can see the "debris" on the deck.  Well worth a run up and then use the common anchor for a practice flight on the line to the right.
content.protection:
BD #2 X 1, #3 X 2, #4 X 2

Chains and a quick link (Same anchor for Crash Landing)
content.location: Middle line on the east face of The Control Tower.

content.description: A shady line in a protected slot, this crack climbs well and takes gear easily.
content.protection: Bring mix of sizes but mostly from BD #1s - #2s X 2 and #3s X 3, one #4, and one #5. You can build a good anchor at the top edge using #3s or top out and find a chain anchor in the center of the TSA Tower and in your same crack.
content.location: Best way in is from the Shangri La campsite trail (see approach trail map).  Follow this SW to the edge.  Here note the cairn atop the TSA Tower and the three cracks below on the towers east face.  Now turn right or north a few hundred feet to a cairned and easy down chute to the stable talus below.  There is a fixed line to aid your decent and guide the way.   Head south along the wall to the gap between the wall and TSA Tower where the three cracks are obvious.  Taildragger is the middle crack.  OR, with extreme caution and a belay, jump from the trail edge to the tower and use the anchor atop to rap to the lines base.

content.description: Easy climbing and in the shade most of the day.  The crux is finding the line though it is only 20 min.s from car to crack.
content.protection: A mix of singles from BD .5 - #2s, two #3s, and one #4.  Also some runners.  You can  easily top out and find the chain anchor dead center of the tower.  A 50 m rope is fine.
content.location: Best way in is from the Shangri La campsite trail (see approach trail map).  Follow this SW to the edge.  Here note the cairn atop the TSA Tower and the three cracks below on the towers east face.  Now turn right or north a few hundred feet to a cairned and easy down chute to the stable talus below.  There is a fixed line to aid your decent and guide the way.   Head south along the wall to the gap between the wall and TSA Tower where the three cracks are obvious.  Student Pilot is the farthest left.  OR, with extreme caution and a belay, jump from the trail edge to the tower and use the anchor atop to rap to the lines base.

climbs.name: Stall & Fall
climbs.fa: R. Suggett, et al. (they wish to remain anonymous)

content.description: The rap in is way better than the talus crux approach.  This is my new favorite line at this grade in the J.  Too bad it could not be longer!
content.protection: Five QDs to the two bolt anchor.
content.location: Just right of the rap-in and the line known as "Instruction Manual" on another arete where you cross right to left at the top.

climbs.name: Small Bag of Salty Peanuts
climbs.fa: D. Pike, R. Suggett, B. Simek, & E. Harris

content.description: Another fine line in the cluster around "The Hangar".  Good rock and well scrubbed as well as crow bared..  No, that bock is/was solid.  Great movement and very thoughtful..
content.protection: Five bolts to chains with a quick link.
content.location: On the blunt arete of "The Hangar's" NE face and just right of the "Hangar's Shadow".

content.description:
Short and bouldery, this line is a slightly more powerful and less technical version of the delicate

Mayday on Monday

to its right.

Start with a seam lieback past a bolt to reach good horizontals rails and setup for a big reach/throw into a sharp corner crack (the first blade of the propeller). Gingerly lieback this short section, taking care not to pull straight out on the large blocks which form the corner (they sound hollow but feel solid). Figure out which feet you can use (hint: none) to throw to another sharp corner, mash your sad fingers in the sharp licheny crack (the second blade of the propeller), and mantle on the ledge from which you can reach the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chain anchors shared with Mayday on Monday. Very well protected, the upper half could go on gear if you trusted the blocks (I don't)
content.location: You'll find the Propeller Blades spinning on a 50' tall panel of clean rock directly left of the approach rappel.

climbs.name: Picked the Wrong Week
climbs.fa: S. Ohkawa, R. Suggett, A. Ross

content.description: Good movement with thoughtful cruxes.  Would get more stars if there was not a bit of choss half way through.
content.protection: QDs and runners to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: On the main wall just south of "The Hangar" and just right of I Speak Jive.  These two lines share the same anchor.  Best to approach by passing between The Hangar and the main wall.

content.description: Rap in or deal with the cruxy talus.  Otherwise, this rather tame OW crack goes easy with face edges.  Short but fun.
content.protection: One #1, one #2, three #3s, two #4s and something for the chains.
content.location: Between "Checking for Structural Integrity" and "Deicing" this crack on the arete shares the same anchor as "Deicing".  All are on the main wall opposite "The Hangar"

content.description: A bouldery start leads to nice face climbing.
content.protection: Bolts
content.location: Starts up the thin seam 10ft right of "Shirley's Corner"

climbs.name: Mayday On Monday
climbs.fa: R. Suggett, A. Mollard, and Ms. Lili

content.description: On good rock and well bolted.  Very thoughtful through all the big throws.  The first throw is a must to clip the third bolt.  A must do in the area!
content.protection: Five QDs  and something for the chain anchor with a quick link.
content.location: Just a bit left of the rap in and/or the route known as Instruction Manual.

climbs.name: Insufficient Landing Strip
climbs.fa: R. Suggett, et al. (they wish to remain anonymous)

content.description: This seldom warm or sunshine lit crack is a respite in the heat of summer.  Worth the trip in and you get some face, mostly hands jamming and a chimney at the top, all easily protected,
content.protection: See picture below.
content.location: Rap down the entry OR do the talus, but this line is in the darkest recesses of the "Hangar"

content.description: Short but good movement for the grade.  Fun line.  Can also serve as the rap-in to the area as well as the exit.  Better than the talus approach.
content.protection: Three bolts to a two bolt chain anchor with a quick link.  There is a huge block up there (see photo) that had me nervously check under, stomp on, crow bar and curse.  Never even came close to giving any indication it would ever move.  That being said, tread lightly and belay off to the side.  The Topo gives the impression the first bolt is a ways off the deck, optical illusion.  Easy first clip on big stance.
content.location: You can follow either trail into the The Air Strip as is outlined on the cover page then walk north or south along the edge (depending on the trail chosen) until you reach a red fixed line off a tree.  This leads to an easily reached anchor to rap in.   OR, take the trail out of the Shangri La camping area to the edge and then walk north to the talus approach also outlined on the cover page.

climbs.name: I Speak Jive
climbs.fa: S. Ohkawa, R. Suggett, A. Ross

content.description: Reachy moves in a sharp crack that takes all the gear you want to place.  As the crack drifts right at the top exit on to the face passing one bolt to chains.
content.protection: Doubles from very small cams to BD # 3 as well as a QD for the bolt, runners to extend gear, and something for the chains.
content.location: On the main wall just behind and south of "The Hangar".   Best to approach from within the shade of The Hangar where there is a cluster of other good lines, eg. The Hangar Shadow.  Shares the same anchor with the sport route  "Picked the Wrong Week" just to the right.

content.description:
This line is possibly on the best best rock yet found in the Jungle.  The tuff feels like Tuolumme Granite and would have four stars if it were only longer.  When warm temps are baking the Air Strip, this line will most certainly be cool and shady.  It lies in a two meter wide slot and faces east.  Getting into this slot between the hangars might be the crux of the entire adventure, however, there are many excellent new routes very nearby making the talus navigation well worth the effort.

The Hangar Shadow line starts on the right of the wall and moves left to center before then moving back right up above.
content.protection: Five bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Follow the directions of the Air Strip's main page as well as these details.  Starting from behind the Shangri La campsite, take the cairned trail southwest to the edge.  Walk north a 100 meters to the well marked fixed line decent.  Follow the cairns and pseudo trail to a fir tree on a hump in the middle of the talus.  From here, zig zag up and south east to the hanging wall and obvious ledge.  Move south into the coolness of the slot passing good lines on your left such as "Mind the Gap".  The Shadow Hangar climb is obvious for its quality of rock.

content.description: Good movement and easy gear placement make this the best of the three lines.  The crux is having enough big gear.
content.protection: Bring a wide variety of cams but especially 4s-5s X 2.  A 50 m rope works well.  Use the chain anchor dead center of the top of TSA Tower.
content.location: Best way in is from the Shangri La campsite trail (see approach trail map).  Follow this SW to the edge.  Here note the cairn atop the TSA Tower and the three cracks below on the towers east face.  Now turn right or north a few hundred feet to a cairned and easy down chute to the stable talus below. There is a fixed line to aid your decent and guide the way.  Head south along the wall to the gap between the wall and TSA Tower where the three cracks are obvious.  Ground Control to Climber Tom is the farthest right.  OR, with extreme caution and a belay, jump from the trail edge to the tower and use the anchor atop to rap to the lines base.  A more stout line (Turbulence) is on the west side of the Tower.

content.description:
An alternative to the bolted

Instruction Manual

to its right, Flight School follows a short section of thin crack to a ledge where it joins with its neighbor, surmounting a large block and finishing in a dihedral.

The climbing is moderate, the stances are good, and the gear is solid. A bit of lichen adds some slickness but overall it makes a good beginner line, nothing too remarkable but that thin crack was too obvious to ignore. If you're in the area with trad gear you might as well put it to good use...
content.protection: Cams from tiny to BD 0.5. Nuts would also work. A draw for the 3rd bolt of IM if you're not willing to trust the lichen placements to the left (which could use a runner).
content.location: FS follows a short diagonaling finger crack immediately below the rappel anchor into the Air Strip.

content.description: Straight forward crack climbing that includes abundant  face edges for those that hate twisting feet.  Fun romp up.  There are many good gear locations in addition to a small horizontal on the face that takes a micro cam well.
content.protection:
Small set of mico cams

BD .75 through #2 X 1, #3s X 2. # 4 X 1

Chains with a quick link
content.location: Farthest left on the east side of The Control tower.

content.description:
Pull through the steep buldge to the ledge. Up the corner to anchor on right.

Little crumbly at start but gets better.
content.protection: Bolts. .4 to 2 Camalots
content.location: The right facing corner 20ft right of Wing Commander. Two bolts at the start lead into the corner.

climbs.name: Deicing
climbs.fa: G. Stroud-Settles, R. Suggett, Janice Stroud-Settles

content.description: Unless you rap in, the crux is the talus approach.  Great rock and movement on a mix of face, crack, and chimney.  Thoughtful climbing.
content.protection: Five QDs, a .4 and a red C-3 with something for the chain anchor.  Shared anchor with Overhanging Cockpit.
content.location: Deep in the dark and frigid recesses of the Hangar, this line sees little sun.  Just right of "Overhanging Cockpit" and on the main wall opposite of the "Hangar Shadow."

content.description: Like most chimneys, this one will also give you pause when leading.  In addition to it's dynamic start, for the most part, the rock is good if you stay on line. This also will help you in locating the gear placements.
content.protection:
Bring a small set of wires and a BD .4

Two QDs for the two bolts and something for the chains.
content.location: Far right on the east face of The Control Tower and the obvious chimney.

climbs.name: Checking For Structural Integrity
climbs.fa: R. Suggett, Phil Wilson, & Terra Holayter

content.description: A slightly over hanging edgy romp where picking the cleaned and scrubbed holds when pumped and desperate is important.  Fun!
content.protection: Five QDs and something for the anchor.
content.location: In the shadow of "The Hangar" opposite the route Hangar Shadow.

content.description: The line starts on the west face then crosses the arete onto the north face where rests are more frequent.  But, as you near the chains, it becomes over hung and the NE arete left hand lieback gives you some flight schooling.  The first bolt also serves as the anchor for the bottom of the fixed line approach to the tower.
content.protection: Five QDs to chains.
content.location: Just north of The Control Tower by 30 feet and on the approach to the same tower. Follow the cairns from the end of the trail to the edge tree that holds the fixed line.  Descend the knoted short and easy rope to a loose chute.  Using the next fixed line surf down the chute (short) to the obvious bolted line.  This is a must do "Approach Protocol" to the lines on The Control Tower!
